Description: Mould-made disc-shaped scaraboid in glazed composition; slightly domed and plain back with straight sides; underside decorated with schematic, but accurate, representation of a scorpion, with eight legs, two claws and a sting; motif stamped rather than incised; pierced through diameter; pale yellow glaze quite well preserved.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie (probably)
Curator's comments: Scorpion is a relatively common theme on scarabs and scaraboids produced at the 'Scarab Factory' in Naukratis (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). They were found at Naukratis itself (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, 8-10) and in many sites across the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 100, type XXVIIIA, subtype A196-203, see especially A203 for this piece). For scorpion motif on scarabs and scaraboids from Naukratis: BM 1886,0401.1607; Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 86.694; Paris, Louvre Museum E8056 bis. 2; Sydney, The Nicholson Museum, University of Sydney NM00.128.7. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 8)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 98 and 100, fig. 20, Type XXVIII A201)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OD.029) (phase 3)
